comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/97539983@N07] I agree, that's the most likely stretch of road but I cannot yet see any absolute identifying points of comparison between the old photo and the modern view.  If someone has a 1940s Sands directory and could please look up the address of F. Perkins, Grocer, Double Bay it would be most helpful.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: One thing you can see,  is that the road is curved,  but the curbing on the right side  has a dead straight section.  You can see this on google earth.

comment.author: 97539983@N07
comment._content: I see what you mean, so you think the straight stretch of road is opposite Knox St. and the photo is taken looking west to east? That would tally with the previous photo of Rose Bay where the tram lines are on the left side of the road as you travel east. I originally thought the photo was taken looking east to west towards Manning St. simply because of the shadows.

comment.author: 104168629@N08
comment._content: The 1952 Sydney Telephone Directory has an entry under GROCERS for Perkins K

comment.author: 104168629@N08
comment._content: The Sydney Telephone Directory for 1952 has an entry under GROCERS for Perkins K&Son  350 New South Head Rd Dble By FM 1744.  There are also ads in the Sydney Morning Herald for a grocer, F. Perkins, Double Bay FM1744 (Thursday 5 October 1939 p. 16, col. d, and Tuesday 15 April 1952, p. 15, col. i).

comment.author: 104168629@N08
comment._content: Ray White Double Bay is now the occupant of 350 New South Head Road, Double Bay.

comment.author: 13267298@N00
65073643@N02
comment._content: The Sands Directory for 1930  (and the photo has date 28 July 1930 in the lower right hand corner) has 330 New South Head Road, Double Bay.    "FM" ie "36" would be the then prefix for the then PMG telephone Exchange covering Double Bay.

comment.author: 65073643@N02
comment._content: Sands 1925 has F J PERKINS at 330 New South Head Road Double Bay (so either NSH Rd was re-numbered or the 1950s address is a short distance further along)

comment.author: 65073643@N02
comment._content:
May I confirm that there was NO prefix "FH"  and in doing so, may I provide a list to help future enquiries 
A = 1;       B = 2;      F = 3;      J = 4;      L = 5;      M = 6;      U = 7;      W = 8;      X = 9;      Y = 0

comment.author: 65073643@N02
comment._content:
SMH 16 Oct 1946  as per TROVE
PERKINS  October 14, 1946, Kate PERKINS of 350 New South Head Road, Double Bay, relict of the late Arthur John Perkins and dearly loved mother of Frederick and Kathleen (Mrs K F PRENDERGAST), AGED 79 YEARS.  Requiescat in pace.  Privately interred Catholic Cemetery.  South Head  Oct 15 1946. 

Archives Investigator has a reference (B.30/649) in the Correspondence files [Valuer General] (Record series 14468) for correspondence (24July 1928 to 13 May 1930)   from a Frederick James PERKINS regarding widening New South Head Road Double Bay  
Archives Investigator as Probate Packet for Frederick James PERKINS DD 19 March 1959, granted 17 Aug 1959. 

Electoral Roll 1930
Frederick James PERKINS 339 New South Head Road, Double Bay, grocer
Katherine William PERKINS 339 New South Head Road, Double Bay, home duties

ER 1933, 36, 37, 
Frederick James PERKINS, 373 New Sth Head rd., Double Bay, grocer
Katherine Lillian PERKINS, 373 N.S.H. rd, home duties

comment.author: 97539983@N07
comment._content:
Miss sticky beak, that is great research, is this stuff freely available on the internet??

This is my conclusiion for the time being, please note all street numbers are New South Head Road, Double Bay according to “Whereis” on  7/10/2013. 
350 is indeed Perkins grocers, 352 is another shop, 354 is a dwelling, 356-366 is the large building which dominates the photo, 368-370 is a 2 story building. 
350, 352 and 354 still have the same buildings albeit 354 has had a shopfront tacked onto the original house, if you look at the original upload (2000x1549) you can see it had a wrought  iron fence in 1930.
356-366 is interesting as the front boundary has a kink in it to follow the road curvature, the large building has a kink at the eastern end to match the road, this can be seen at the roofline and also the awning near where the utility pole goes through. The present building does NOT have this kink, so it does not match up with 368, instead there is a now 1 metre “step” between these buildings, which can be plainly seen on Google street view.
368-370 is possibly the 1930 building with an extra floor added.
372-374 is most likely the existing building, it has an ornate  façade above the awning which cannot be seen in the 1930 photo possibly because it’s painted white.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/97539983@N07/10155128535/]
